awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research - Discordant Models of Testosterone Function
awd_abstract_narration:
Discordant Models of Testosterone Function 

The project will study two opposing models of the nature and function of testosterone from two scientific fields (endocrinology and human performance physiology). According to the first, testosterone is thought to drop in response to training, differ sharply in levels between men and women, and to be the chief ingredient in performance; in the other, testosterone is thought to sharply rise in response to interventions, to produce highly variable effects, and to be an inadequate predictor of performance. New 'hyperandrogenism' rules draw on the first model only, though that model might not be the most relevant for the scientific questions involved. 

The research is likely to contribute not only to academic debates but also influence how the public thinks about these issues, as well as help to shape organizational policies. In addition, two graduate students will be trained in qualitative data analysis.

por.por_cntn:
This project was an investigation of complex and contradictory scientific understandings of the production and functioning of testosterone (T) in humans. Our study was prompted by the implementation of controversial new international sports policies restricting the participation of women athletes with naturally high levels of T. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF), the International Olympic Committee (IOC), and other sports organizations maintain that women with naturally high T have an “unfair advantage” over other women athletes. Under these so-called “hyperandrogenism” policies, women with naturally high T are allowed to compete in international-level competitions only if they are apparently “insensitive” to T (that is, they don’t have typical androgen receptors) or they agree to have medical or surgical interventions to lower their T, even if such interventions are not medically indicated. Although reliance on particular scientific experts and evidence has been a key strategy in crafting and defending these policies, the degree to which the policies are “scientifically” justifiable has been quite contentious, even among scientific experts.

Elite sports organizations have long sought a biological method to validate women for participation in gender-segregated competitions. But biological sex is complex, and no definitive attribute or set of attributes can objectively divide all males from all females. For example, some women have the “male-typical” XY karyotype pattern, and an earlier version of sports sex testing that relied on karyotype testing was found to be scientifically unfounded and discriminatory. Testosterone, as a precisely defined molecule that sporting officials describe as a “marker” of sex and the “main ingredient” in athletic success, has been touted as a better criterion. Yet T is itself an object of profound scientific disagreements, especially concerning how T is produced and functions in female athletes. In some scientific accounts, T simply drives athleticism; in others, the relationship between athleticism and T is reciprocal (that is, T can affect athletic traits like strength, but training or participating in competitions can dramatically raise T). Some scientists maintain that very high T in women is a sign of abnormality or poor health, while other scientists disagree, in part because there are women athletes with no health complaints who have very high T. Contrary to policymakers’ claims and popular wisdom, there is no direct evidence linking higher levels of T to “male typical” athletic performance in women. This last point has been especially crucial in a recent legal challenge to the policies: in 2015, the Court of Arbitration for Sport suspended these policies for two years.  Unless sports organizations can provide clearer scientific evidence regarding the supposed “advantage” that high endogenous T confers, the policies will be permanently revoked and women with naturally high T will be allowed to compete.

Because the science of T is not unitary, policies on eligibility of female athletes with naturally high T inevitably draw upon particular social and biological versions of T and modes of linking T to athleticism. These policies have profound effects not only on how athletes are regulated, but also on ideas about gender, strength, and the relation between sex and race, especially given that these policies disproportionately affect women of color from the Global South. With the stakes so high, it is crucial to understand how policy makers and concerned publics can choose the “best” science for the questions at hand. Over the course of three years, we compiled and extracted a large body of research literature on testosterone, comparing highly-cited work from research domains in which scientists use significantly different models and approaches in order to identify gaps and contradictions in the work. We interviewed sports policymakers, scientists, athletes, coaches, and clinicians who treat conditions associated with high or low T, and conducted participant-observation at scientific and professional meetings. With our presentations and publications, we have raised awareness and have stimulated additional debate about the hyperandrogenism policy among athletes, advocates, coaches, trainers, administrators, scientists, clinicians, sports journalists, ethicists, and others. Further, we have stimulated conversations among diverse international communities that are rare opportunities to discuss: 1) the complexity of biological sex; 2) the role of gender and racial ideologies in public discussions of individuals' sex or sex in general; 3) how different experts produce, select, evaluate, and weigh potentially conflicting evidence for making policy decisions; and 4) the proper role of scientific experts and evidence in deciding specific ethical questions about inclusion, exclusion, and fairness.
